statement.p: Recall our work with limits involving infinity earlier in the book. State clearly what it means for a continuous function f to have a limit L as x \to \infty.

hint.p: A function f has limit L as x \to \infty if we can make f(x) as close to L as we like by \ldots.

solution.p: A continuous function f has a limit L as the independent variable x goes to infinity if we can make the values of f(x) as close to L as we want by choosing x as large as we need.

statement.p: Given that an infinite sequence of real numbers is a function from the integers to the real numbers, apply the idea from part (a) to explain what you think it means for a sequence \{s_n\} to have a limit as n \to \infty.

hint.p: Think about making s_n as close as you want to L for large values of n.

solution.p: We expect that a sequence \{s_n\} will have a limit L as n goes to infinity if we can make the entries s_n in the sequence as close to L as we want by choosing n as large as we need.

statement.p: Based on your response to the part (b), decide if the sequence \left\{ \frac{1+n}{2+n}\right\} has a limit as n \to \infty. If so, what is the limit? If not, why not?

solution.p: As n gets large, the constant terms become infinitesimally small compared to n and so \frac{1+n}{2+n} looks like \frac{n}{n} or 1 for large n. So the sequence \left\{ \frac{1+n}{2+n}\right\} has a limit of 1 at infinity.
